fields.label_text:
CHALICE AND PATEN
Silver-gilt
Bowl engraved: pater de celis deus Miserere nobis. 
Foot engraved: sancta maria ora pro nobis
Paten inscribed: sancta trinitas unus deus Miserere nobis
Found in 1749 during the demolition of Pillaton Hall, Staffordshire
English; about 1530
Acquired with the assistance of the Worshipful Company of Goldsmiths, the National Art-Collections Fund and the Pilgrim Trust

fields.physical_description:
Chalice and Paten. Silver-gilt. English, about 1530. Shallow bowl with back engraved in black letter: PATER. DE CELIS DEUS MISERERE NOBIS  with a pomegranite and rosettes between words. Hexagonal parelled stem depressed spherical knot engraved with tracery and set with six rosettes. Domed six lobed base, having round the base of the stem an arcade divided by butresses; engraved in black letter; SANCTA MARIA ORA PRO NOBIS.

Paten with double depression, rim engraved in black letters: SANCTA TRINITAS UNUS DEUS MISERERE NOBIS sexfoil depression with alternate spandrels engraved with roses and Stafford Knots (?) in the centre IHS.

Case. Oak, with door set with a silver plaque inscribed 'CALICEM SACERRIM CVLTVI OLIM DICATUM ET IN PILLATENANO SVO VBI DIV OB TEMPORVM CALAMITATES ABDITVS LATVERAT A VIRO CLARISSIMO EDVARDO ANNO MDCCL REPERTVM EDVARDVS JOHANNES PRIMUS BARO HATHERTONENSIS IN HAC CAPSA EX AVITAE DOMVS TRABE CONFECTA PRO MAIORE REVERENTIA ET TUTELA REDONENDVM CVRAVIT ANNO CI_I_   CCCLVI.
London hallmark for 1856. Front in form of a depressed arch (enclosing the door with silver plate) flanked by two pinnacles, shaped square base. When exhibited in the society of Aniquaries it was stated that the inscription had been provided by Cardinal Wiseman.

Height : 21 1/2 inches Width : 12 inches
fields.dimensions: Height: 7 in chalice, Diameter: 5 7/8 in Paten

CHALICE AND PATEN
Silver-gilt
Bowl engraved: pater de celis deus Miserere nobis. 
Foot engraved: sancta maria ora pro nobis
Paten inscribed: sancta trinitas unus deus Miserere nobis
Found in 1749 during the demolition of Pillaton Hall, Staffordshire
English; about 1530

fields.credit: Purchased with the assistance of The Art Fund, the Goldsmith's Company and the Pilgrim Trust
fields.history_note: When exhibited at the Royal Society of Antiquaries on March 12th 1885, it was stated that the chalice and paten had been discovered in a small cupboard together with a number of bags containing coins  in the course of the partial demolition of Pillaton Hall in 1750 (Pro. Soc. Ant, 2nd S., X, 260-2). A document from the Hatherton archives now in the Stafford County Record Office (D.260 M//F 4B pp. 38-41) gives an acount made in 1760 of the finding of the money but makes no mention at all of the chalice and paten. Actuially there wrere two discoveries of money, one in 1741 and the other in 1749 (and no mention of the discovery of anything in 1750). The descriptions of the coins mention guineas were first coined in the reign of Charles II, and 'johns' in the reign of Joao V of Portugal (1708-1750) it is obvious that the coins can have been hidden for quite a short time only. Since there appears to be no contemporary description of the finding of the chalice and paten, it is possible to doubt whether it was in fact found with the coins. The Littletonsdo not appear ever to have been recusants and the chalice and paten are rather finer than might be expected to be found in the chapel  of a small manor house. It has been suggested (c.c. Oman"English Church Plate" 119) that the chalice and paten might originally have belonged to St Thomas's Abbey near Stafford; since at the time of the Dissolution two members of the Littleton family had pieces of the Abby plate in pledge.
